column2: This covenant makes claim to be the aristocracy of the night
Covenant seeks to influence Kindred society with the strictures of Longinus, who is believed to have been turned into one of the Damned by the very blood of Christ
Vampires who believe the mother of Longinus was also a vampire.  A syncretic heretical merger of the Testament of Longinus with the Circle of the Crone
Covenant of vampires who secretly hunt vampires
Kindred who follow the Testament of Longinus
Cala Senecta: the Wing of Ancients. The leadership and nobility of the Camarilla. This is also the name of the voting governmental body which mirrors the Roman Senate of the mortals.
The Legio Mortuum: The Legion of the Dead, the Camarilla’s military arm and strongest means of maintaining its traditions.
Cala Vaticinium: The Wing of Prophets.  The Cult of Augurs are the dark priesthood of the Camarilla connecting the vampires to the Roman gods and keeping Rome in their good graces.

Cala Hospitia: the Wing of Strangers.  Foreigners are not shunned from the Camarilla, but they will never be made full citizens until they fully adopt Roman customs and law. Outsiders band together in this low-caste wing
Monotheistic vampires in the Abrahamic traditions of the Levant
Covenant venerates a variety of female figures as an amalgamated creator of vampires, the Mother of all Monsters
The Blood Blessed of the Celts
The Sacred People of the Saxons, the Woods-Witches
Not a covenant at all, but rather individuals who are independent
These kindred believe they are the daughters of Mara, the demon who tempted the Budhha.
These kindred are the inversion of Jainist beliefs.
The indigenous kindred covenant of Africa.
Noble vampire clans of Europe: Brujah, Cappadocian, Lasombra, Toreador and Ventrue
The Ventrue high clan of vampires
The Toreador high clan of vampires
The Brujah high clan of vampires
The Lasombra high clan of vampires
The Cappadocian high clan of vampires
The Salubri high clan of vampires
The rabble vampire clans of Europe: Gangrel, Malkavian and Nosferatu
Vampire rebels against their established order
Vampire Brujah who want to recreate Carthage where kindred and kine live in harmony

column3: a covenant of vampires who have rebelled against their sires

column2: Warlocks who have become vampires through sorcery
Scions of Itügen. The Gangrel bloodline of Dobrul the Brave, found among Mongols and other Altaic peoples
Odin's brood, the All-High's chosen warriors of Ragnarok, Norse Gangrel vampires
Children of the Midnight Sun, Gangrel vampires among the Finnish and Uguric peoples
Not all Camarilla vampires are of the seven clans
The Sword of Caine, formed by anarchs who refused to submit to the Camarilla
The hidden ones, a reclusive sect of Roman vampires
The Oradea League is made up of Old Clan Tzimisce who refuse to join the Sabbat or the Camarilla
Vampires outside of sect or clan
Beastial werewolves who want no company with man
Banished from Egypt by the curse of Sutekh, these werewolves wander the deserts
Mongrel werewolves found in city slums
Spread from the Eurasian Steppes to the lands of Hungary, Slavs and the Balkans

The Nameless are a collection of factions and cabals of apostates that refused the authority of the Diamond Orders and rebelled against them. After making peace, the Nameless then formed the Free Council, turning the Diamond into a Pentacle. Most of the Nameless who did not join the Free Council were destroyed, though many pockets remain.

The Adamantine Arrow are an order of mages that claim descent from members of the Ungula Draconis (Claw of the Dragon) who protected the shards of fallen Atlantis. They are the most militaristic of the Diamond Orders and act as defenders to the legitimate heirs of Atlantis.

The Guardians of the Veil are an order of mages that claim descent from members of the Visus Draconis (Eye of the Dragon). They act as the enforcers, secret police, and spies for the Lex Magica and Consilii that hold its tenets.

The Mysterium are an order of mages that claim descent from members of the Alae Draconis (Dragon's Wing), the research and development branch of Atlantean society. Now they seek to reclaim the lore lore of the world and remember the lessons of fallen Atlantis.

The Silver Ladder are an order of mages that claim descent from Atlantean priests and viziers known as the Vox Draconis (Dragon's Voice). They believe in mankind's inherent right to divinity and magic.

Mammon, the Feeder of Greed or Gushasu-Nihur, is one of the nine Maeljin (powerful spirits who rule over a plane of spirits known as the Shadow). He appears as a skeletal angel with pale skin and bat wings. He plagues any Cahalith near his Wounds with visions of want and hunger.

The Father is one of the four Archigenitor Exarchs, the main rulers of the Fallen World. He grants his servants power over Doctrine and his Ministry is Paternoster. The Father is the Exarch of Prime and is considered by his followers to be the origin of revealed religion.

Panopitcon is an organization of technocrats created by Control itself. It's main purpose is to enforce Control's directives and keep the Traditions (the Technocrats' rivals) fractured and broken. A secondary task is the silent enforcement of the assimilation of reality and the destruction of threatening Reality Deviants.

The Scelesti, or the Accursed, are mages who chose to gain power through service to the Abyss, their souls tainted by allowing the void to merge with them. Due to this, they are often perceived as mad and often executed.
The Timori are mages that steal mana from other mages in order to become immortal. This has the disadvantage of causing an intense addiction and turning them into living corpses.
An Orphan is a mage who has learned magic without a formal tutor. They are often prejudiced as loose cannons and threats to those around them.
The Valdaermen are Nordic practitioners of rune magic.

The Order of Hermes is one of the pillars of the Traditions. They were Founded in 767 in an event known as the Pax Hermetica. Obsessed with perfection, they are easily the most hierarchical and prestigious of the Traditions.
The Messianic Voices' paradigm was built on a Foundation of Divinity (Relationship to the Divine), which empowered the Singers to call on the aid of four Archangels.
The Nif'ur en'Daah (Eaters of the Weak) are an Infernalist sect of mages.
